title: Personal Logo
content:
Hello   
   
I'm trying to develop a logo for freelance work, to be used initially on a business card, letterhead, etc. Maybe later on a website.   
I would like to keep the mark type only.   
My name is Robert King.   
   
Here are four ideas. These are all in grayscale at this point... I will address color when I am closer to a final design.   
   
The "KD" stands for "King Design," although as you can see from the other options, I'm flexible about how my name is listed.   
   
I like the 1920s-looking faces, because I'm leaning towards a non-coporate image, but I tried a variety here to get some reactions.   
   
The fonts are, in order: Adobe Garamond, Bitstream Clarendon Light, Toot Sweet and Bergling Fantasia, both by Nick Curtis.   
   
Any comments would be much appreciated.   
   
Thanks,   
   
Rob   
   
 ![clarendon](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019034711im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/22932.jpg) ![garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019034711im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/22933.jpg) ![toot sweet](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019034711im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/22934.jpg) ![bergling](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019034711im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/22935.jpg)
author: rking

comments.content:
I like the last, but there seems to be a little too much air in the interior of the "G". It may need to be narrowed a bit, and maybe pull the spur up so the logo doesn't run all the way downhill.   
   
Have you considered being the "design king"?
I like the verticle knock out version it has a 50's retro feel. Try taking the cross bar on the k and make it break the rectangle too. Also make the g break the rectangle cleanly.
